prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 continuum (& CO) group1of2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The goal of this project to detect Band 3 continuum emission of 12 young low mass stars and brown dwarfs in the Taurus star-forming region. This sample is drawn from our existing Cycle 1 Band 7 continuum and CO(3-2) program. In order to investigate of both the disk dust and gas properties around these very low mass objects, we additionally target CO(1-0) emission in this follow up study.
This is a dectection project and the sources are expected to be unresolved.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The correlator setup is driven by the science requirement to detect the continuum emission at 3mm to measure the spectral slopes, but also designed to enable the detection of the CO(1-0) gas line. Three of the four basebands of the correlator are set to the widest 2 GHz (1.875GHz useable) bandwidth to ensure the highest sensitivity map in the minimum amount of time. The remaining baseband is centered over the CO(1-0) line at 115.271 GHz in frequency division mode with the maximum baseband width (0.9375 GHz) that is configurable at this frequency. The total aggregate bandwidth is therefore 6.56 GHz. Approximately, 1 min additional on source integration time per target is needed to account for the ~0.9 GHz loss in bandwidth in observing at this frequency range.
With this total bandwidth, the 1 sigma rms noise level will reach 0.03 mJy in 12 min on-source, ensuring a 3sigma detection of 0.09 mJy which corresponds to the more extreme case of a spectral slope alpha=2.5. The sensitivity in the line channels will reach 8 mJy / channel, which is comparable to the fluxes measured for the CO(3-2) line for 10 of the 12 sources with line detections from our Cycle 1 program. The CO(1-0) should be detected for these sources.

Because the study is centered on the measurement of the flux level of the disk emission, this project is not constrained by angular resolution. We do not need to resolve the disks at this stage, but the results of this program will provide an ideal target set for follow-up investigations to spatially resolve spectral index gradients. The maximum desired angular resolution is 1.0, which is achievable in the C36-4 configuration with a maximum baseline of 970 km. For this program, the essential step is to obtain accurate measurements of the flux level at 3mm across the stellar/substellar boundary. Of the 12 targets, all but one have been observed with high spatial resolution optical / infrared imaging; none has a resolved companion within the ALMA beam of the maps which would impact the interpretation of the results. Based on the Herschel maps, it is also known that there are no additional sub-mm sources in the field. Using the simobserve and simanalyze packages within CASA, we generated synthetic images that confirm even the proposed images have high fidelity maps, without sidelobes that would complicate the interpretation.

The target exposure times, observation wavelength and ALMA baseline and correlator configurations have been selected to achieve the science goal of detecting protoplanetary disks encircling young low mass stars and brown dwarfs. Given our previous detections at 885microns, the longer 3mm wavelength is required for the measurement of the spectral slope. The longer wavelengths are also better suited for estimates of disk dust and gas mass due to their more optically thin emission. The sensitivity limit for the study is set at an rms noise level of 0.03 mJy for a 3sigma detection limit of 0.09mJy which represents the extrapolation of the faintest detections from our Cycle 1 program assuming a spectral slope alpha=2.5. Even a non-detection for any of the sources would place a strong limit on the amount of grain growth present within the disk; an upper limit would mean the disk has grains with a size distribution similar to the ISM. Each target requires 12 min of on-source time to reach the required sensitivity level. To facilitate these long wavelength observations being used as filler tracks, the targets have been put into two groups of 6 targets (~2 hour total integration time per group), rather than requesting a longer observation sequence. Since the setup is the same for all targets and all targets are within a 10 degree region, a single science goal is applied (as confirmed with the ALMA helpdesk ticket#6673).
A total of 4.3 hours is required to complete the observations and associated calibrations for the full sample of 12 targets with default weather conditions used in the OT octile 6 for Taurus. This order of magnitude increase in sensitivity possible only with ALMA is needed to transform the understanding of the disks around low mass stars and brown dwarfs and investigate the early stages of planet formation. As shown in Figure 3, the large-scale surveys of disks around more massive pre-Main Sequence Stars in Taurus with spectral types from K to early-M show a range of approximately one order of magnitude in disk fluxes, but existing limits for late-M stars and brown dwarfs are only sufficient to detect the brightest disks for now. To explore the diversity of disk properties and not simply detect the brightest disks present around low mass objects the factor of 10 improvement only possible with ALMA is required.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Circumstellar disks are central for the formation of planets. Their ability to form planets depends on their mass and ability to grow dust into larger particles. With the ALMA sensivity and an ideal sample of 12 young, low mass objects, we propose to get 3mm maps to measure the dust properties of protoplanetary disks over the stellar/substellar transition. By targeting objects already detected at 885um in our Cy1 ALMA program, each too faint for follow-up with any other facility, we maximize the detection probability and the SED coverage, important for the characterization of disk properties. ALMA is essential to move from a small number of detections (brightest low mass objects) to a comprehensive understanding of brown dwarf disk properties. Currently, only 3 Taurus low mass objects (spty. M4-M8) have measured spectral slopes. With the proposed ALMA observations, we will observe four times this number and enable an investigation of the more typical disks. By targeting the lowest mass members of the well known Taurus region, we will efficiently complete a comprehensive population study across the full mass spectrum by combining the proposed ALMA study with existing measurements.
